questions.text: Hurler’s syndrome (an autosomal recessive disease) patients have mutations at the L-iduronidase gene locus. The diagnosis of Hurler’s syndrome can be made by analyzing a patient’s DNA for:

options.label: A
options.text: The entire set of genes in any cell

options.label: B
options.text: Altered position of the L-iduronidase gene on a chromosome

options.label: C
options.text: A region of DNA that does not encode RNA

options.label: D
options.text: A mutant allele of the L-iduronidase gene

questions.correct_answer: D. A mutant allele of the L-iduronidase gene
questions.explanation:
Solution:

A mutant allele of the L-iduronidase gene To confirm the defective enzyme, the most efficient DNA diagnosis would be to analyze for the presence of any mutation in the DNA sequence (nucleotide substitutions, deletions, duplications) of L-iduronidase genes in this patient which would further reveal the altered function of the L-iduronidase protein. Human autosomes (chromosomes 1 through 22) and X chromosomes in females have two homologous loci in each individual, with two identical (homozygous) or different (heterozygous) alleles. Due to the autosomal recessive nature of the Hurler disease, both alleles have to be mutated for the patient to show a phenotype. So, in this patient, absence of normal copy of the gene and the presence of only a mutated copy of the L-iduronidase gene will be a confirmatory test of Hurler Syndrome.

questions.text: A newborn baby has a sibling with sickle cell anemia and is at risk for the disease. The appropriate diagnostic test for sickle cell anemia in this baby will include:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

DNA amplification To obtain sufficient amounts of DNA for hemoglobin genes, DNA from the leukocytes of the patient can be amplified using polymerase chain reaction (PCR). The portion of the β-globin gene that harbors the sickle cell anemia mutation can be amplified using specific primers, complementary to the flanking region of the β-globin gene. After PCR, the product is fixed on a support and Allele-specific Hybridization using two allele-specific oligonucleotides (ASO) probes one for the normal hemoglobin and one for defective hemoglobin A mutation (S mutation) will be used. These can reveal the presence of normal (AA alleles), sickle trait (AS alleles), or sickle cell anemia (SS alleles).

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options- Option: A. Newborns have fetal hemoglobin (α- and γ-globin) with little expression of hemoglobin A (α- and β-globin genes) until 3 to 6 months of life, so testing for anemia or abnormal hemoglobin with antibodies would not be helpful. Options: B and C. Restriction cutting and RFLPs analysis produce a pattern of restriction fragments and is highly distinctive for each individual (DNA fingerprinting) but not diagnostic for a particular disease.

questions.text: A patient presented with complaints of fever, cough, back pain, runny nose, and breathing difficulties to the outpatient department. He was a suspected case of COVID-19. Which technique will be best to confirm the diagnosis:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Real-Time Reverse Transcriptase PCR The best test to detect Covid-19 viral infection is real-time Reverse Transcriptase PCR (rRT-PCR) assay. In this assay, the swab sample from the nose is used. The amount of viral nucleic acid present in the sample gives an estimation of the extent of infection. The viral RNA in the sample is first converted to cDNA using Reverse transcriptase enzyme and then cDNA is detected and quantified using viral-specific primers in a PCR reaction performed and monitored in real-time using fluorescent probes or dye. When the fluorescence reaches a particular threshold, the sample is said to be positive for virus infection. By monitoring how many cycles it takes to reach this level, one can determine the severity of the infection: the fewer cycles, the more severe the viral infection is. Dyes used in real time PCR SYBR based detection TaqMan based detection ● Uses SYBR Green dye ● ds-DNA binding dye ● Not sequence specific ● Uses a fluorogenic probe specific to target gene ● It accumulates during PCR.

questions.text: miRNA are small, endogenous, non-coding, double-stranded RNA naturally present in plants, animals, and viruses for regulation of gene expression by post-transcriptional gene silencing (PTGS). During the silencing mechanism, what is the approximate size of miRNA molecules produced by Dicer nuclease?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

22 bp MicroRNAs in PTGS : Dicer is an endonuclease that trims small double-stranded RNA (pre-miRNA) and generates short, double-stranded (ds) miRNA molecules (22 nucleotides long approx.) that can block translation. Dicer cleaves the cytosolic dsRNA encoded by the genome or exogenously supplied as oligonucleotides miRNA or siRNA A single strand (the guide or antisense strand) of the ds miRNA associates with RNA-induced silencing complex, or RISC afterwards to bind to target mRNA to block translation.

questions.text: CRISPR-Cas9 is a unique technology that enables geneticists and medical researchers to edit parts of the genome by removing, adding, or altering sections of the DNA sequence. Which of the following DNA repair mechanisms is part of CRISPR/Cas9-mediated gene editing?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Non-Homologous End Joining CRISPR The CRISPR system represents a form of acquired immunity to infection by bacteriophages, which complements the system of restriction endonucleases and methylases. CRISPR uses RNA-based targeting to bring the Cas9 nuclease to foreign (or any complementary) DNA. Within the bacteria this CRISPR-RNA-Cas9 complex degrades and inactivates targeted DNA. Use- gene deletion, gene editing, and even modulation of gene transcription. CRISPR-mediated gene therapy works on the basis of both homologous and non-homologous end-joining DNA repair mechanism

Solution:

questions.text: An expression vector is used for protein synthesis while a cloning vector is just used for multiplying the gene of interest. Which of the following components is necessarily present in the expression vector but not in the cloning vector?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Ribosomal entry site As, in the expression vector, the DNA of interest is expressed as RNA and proteins, so, the promoter which is needed for transcription, and Shine-Dalgarno sequence (ribosomal entry site) which is needed for translation initiation has to be present in this vector. Without these two, the protein cannot be synthesized. Whereas cloning vectors are not used for protein synthesis, so, no transcription or translation need to be done, so promoter and ribosomal entry sites are not necessarily added in these vectors. All the other three components mentioned in the question are present in both vectors as they are required for initiation of replication (option a), inserting the gene of interest (option b), and selection of recombinant vector (option c) which is the requirement for both kinds of vectors.

questions.text: The process used to prevent the recircularization of the sticky ends of DNA is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Homopolymer tailing The process used to prevent the recircularization of the stick ends of DNA is Homopolymer tailing Homopolymer tailing Involves adding a series of nucleotides on the 3’OH termini of a double-stranded DNA molecule using enzyme terminal deoxynucleotidyl transferase. A homopolymer tail is produced in the presence of one deoxynucleotide. Prevents recircularization of the stick ends of DNA For the ligation of two-tailed molecules, the homopolymers must be complementary.

questions.text: RFLP analysis using site flanking the ApoB100 gene on chromosome 2 among members of a family with a history of Hypercholesterolemia yielded one large fragment and one smaller fragment that is also seen in controls. What is the probable inheritance mechanism in this family:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Autosomal dominant The large fragment could either have been derived from a mutation removing one flanking restriction site or from extra DNA inserted between the restriction sites. The fact that there are two DNA fragment sizes in the affected individual but one in controls suggests alteration of only one of the two homologous apoB 100 genes on chromosome 2. Only in an autosomal or sex-linked dominant inheritance, the disease is produced when even one of the alleles of a gene is mutated. As the gene apoB 100 mentioned here is present on an autosomal chromosome so this is a case of autosomal dominant mutation.

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Option: A. In X-linked recessive inheritance, disease phenotype is produced when both the alleles are mutated in a female and a male even when only one of the alleles is mutated. Option: C. In autosomal recessive inheritance, disease phenotype is produced only when both the alleles are mutated in both males and females. Individuals with a single mutant allele are considered as a carrier for the disease.

questions.text: Isoenzymes hexokinase and glucokinase catalyze the phosphorylation of glucose to glucose 6-phosphate in the first step of glycolysis. However, due to differences in their catalytic parameters, their tissue specificity differs. Hexokinase is present in most tissues and cells while liver tissue also has a high concentration of glucokinase. A researcher is carrying out experiments to know which other tissue show glucokinase expression in addition to the liver. Which of the following techniques would be most useful for this researcher?

options.label: A
options.text: Western blot analysis to detect RNA

options.label: B
options.text: Northern blot analysis to detect RNA

options.label: C
options.text: Southern blot analysis to detect DNA

options.label: D
options.text: Southern blot analysis to detect RNA

questions.correct_answer: B. Northern blot analysis to detect RNA
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Northern blot analysis to detect RNA Expression analysis of an enzyme or protein involves the detection of the corresponding mRNA of that enzyme. A very basic technique to do that is called Northern blot analysis. In this technique, RNA is detected by hybridization to a complementary labeled DNA to form a (DNA-RNA hybridization). In this example, the detection of glucokinase mRNA from the liver and other tissue samples would demonstrate which cells in addition to liver cells are expressing glucokinase. A DNA probe for glucokinase will simply be a small part of the genetic DNA sequence of glucokinase enzyme labeled with a fluorescent dye/radioactive bases.

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Option: A. Western blot analysis is used to detect protein, not RNA. Options: C and D. Southern blot analysis detect DNA (Not RNA) with the use of a DNA probe to bind to the sample DNA. In this case, as the DNA of both enzymes are present in all the tissue, detection of DNA sequences would not be able to tell whether that DNA is expressed or not in that cell. Only a RNA analysis would provide this information.

questions.text: A Ph.D. researcher is studying the mechanisms of generation of mutations in beta-Covid strains of coronavirus. For this investigation, the scientist needs to use a technique by which he can amplify the sequence of DNA shown below: 5' GCTAATGAT ------------ ATATGGCTA 3' He decides to use polymerase chain reaction (PCR) in order to do so. Which of the following would be the most appropriate DNA primer to use for this cycle of PCR?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

5'-TAGTAATCG; 5'- TAGCCATAT For a Polymerase chain reaction (PCR), two primers are required, one that binds to the strand shown in the above image (i.e. the coding strand) and a second that binds to its complementary strand (i.e. the noncoding strand). The primer of the coding strand is complementary to its 3' end. The primer to the noncoding strand is identical to the coding strand's 5' end. To summarize, in order to copy a segment of DNA via PCR, a complementary primer to the 3' end is required along with a reversed copy of the 5' end. To design the primers for this strand, the following steps are performed: Determine the complementary strand to the one displayed, which will be: 3' CGATTACTA -------- TATACCGAT 5' Determine the primer that will hybridize to the strand shown in the question, which will be starting from the 3' end of the original strand since the polymerase moves in the 5'-3' direction. The primer will be 3 ' TATACCGAT, which is conventionally written as 5' TAGCCATAT 3', which is the first primer. Determine the primer that will hybridize to the complementary strand in (step 1), and the primer will be 5' TAGTAATCG 3', which is the second primer.

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Option: A) These primers do not hybridize with either strand of DNA. Option B) Both these primers hybridize to the same strand of DNA (the coding strand). In order for PCR to amplify DNA, there must be a primer for both strands. Option: C) The two specific oligonucleotide primers used for PCR need to hybridize with the 3' ends of both the coding and noncoding DNA strands. This is because DNA synthesis of the new strand proceeds from 5' to 3'. These primers hybridize to the 5' ends of each DNA strand. Option: D) These primers both hybridize to the same strand of DNA (the noncoding strand). In order for PCR to amplify DNA, there must be a primer for both strands.
